name: (2E)-3-Phenylacrylaldehyde
Reason: The basic unit we will consider is styrene, which has a melting point of -30.6°C. This compound has an aldehyde group in place of one of styrene's alkenyl hydrogens. The aldehyde group is polar and introduces some dipole-dipole interactions, but it does not contribute to significant intermolecular hydrogen bonding as no H is attached to the O. Generally, an aldehyde group would increase the boiling point due to polarity but has a less pronounced effect on the melting point compared to boiling point. We can estimate the aldehyde group increases melting point around +5 to +10 degrees. Combining this with the base of styrene, we predict the melting point to be between -25.6 and -20.6°C.
Test (Predicted reason):
The basic unit, benzene, has a melting point of 5.5°C. The addition of a phenyl group to benzene increases the melting point due to increased molecular weight and pi-pi interactions. The aldehyde group (-CHO) can form hydrogen bonds, which typically increases the melting point. However, the presence of the aldehyde group also introduces polarity, which can disrupt the crystal lattice, potentially lowering the melting point. The overall effect of the phenyl group and the aldehyde group on the melting point is complex and depends on the specific molecular context. In this case, the phenyl group is expected to increase the melting point by approximately 20°C, while the aldehyde group might decrease it by about 5°C due to the disruption of the crystal lattice.
